issue.title: Compilation ERR: Missing `/include` directory on Arch-based distros
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
A bug appears while compiling `oqs-provider` on Arch-based distros. Happens too on the AUR packages [oqsprovider](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/oqsprovider) and [oqsprovider-git](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/oqsprovider-git).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run Arch Linux or some other distro based on it.
2. A Simple way to get into the error is installing `yay` and running as superuser `yay -Sy --noconfirm oqsprovider`.
3. After building `liboqs` and at the beginning of configuring `oqs-provider` it errors.

**Expected behavior**
A `oqs-provider` shouldn't error and compile just fine. **And it should look for `include` directory inside `/usr` / `/usr/lib` / `/usr/lib64` / `/usr/local/lib` (...) too.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/assets/115881539/259671b3-b8a7-4b5a-a578-07fc88b9d81b)


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: `Artix Linux OpenRC Rolling` / `Arch Linux`
 - OpenSSL version: `3.1.1`
 - oqsprovider version: `latest /0.5.1`

 - OpenSSL: `OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023 (Library: OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023)` 
 - For oqsprovider: 
```
Providers:
  default
    name: OpenSSL Default Provider
    version: 3.1.1
    status: active
```

**Additional context**
 - Command used on the git repository: `cmake -S . -B _build && cmake --build _build && ctest --test-dir _build && cmake --install _build`

comment.body:
Thanks for the Dockerfile. But it fails. After debugging, this simplified Dockerfile puzzles me:

```
FROM archlinux

RUN useradd yay
RUN mkdir -p /home/yay && \
    chown -R yay:yay /home/yay && ls -la /home/yay

WORKDIR /home/yay
RUN ls -la /home/yay && ls -la . && pwd
```

results when build via `docker build --no-cache -t yay-archlinux -f Dockerfile-archlinux-fails .`:

```
Sending build context to Docker daemon  3.584kB
Step 1/5 : FROM archlinux
 ---> 1105a6ef0052
Step 2/5 : RUN useradd yay
 ---> Running in 97ab31268d2a
Removing intermediate container 97ab31268d2a
 ---> 7ddfd7557de0
Step 3/5 : RUN mkdir -p /home/yay &&     chown -R yay:yay /home/yay && ls -la /home/yay
 ---> Running in defd5f8aa9e1
total 8
drwxr-xr-x 2 yay  yay  4096 Aug 14 06:23 .
drwxr-xr-x 1 root root 4096 Aug 14 06:23 ..
Removing intermediate container defd5f8aa9e1
 ---> e1bb58118de1
Step 4/5 : WORKDIR /home/yay
 ---> Running in 7449b2b50cac
Removing intermediate container 7449b2b50cac
 ---> 0739edebd3fa
Step 5/5 : RUN ls -la /home/yay && ls -la . && pwd
 ---> Running in e707d23a5f56
total 8
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Aug 14 06:23 .
drwxr-xr-x 1 root root 4096 Aug 14 06:23 ..
total 8
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Aug 14 06:23 .
drwxr-xr-x 1 root root 4096 Aug 14 06:23 ..
/home/yay
Removing intermediate container e707d23a5f56
 ---> 1f5a0816c656
Successfully built 1f5a0816c656
Successfully tagged yay-archlinux:latest
```

Any idea what archlinux / docker do here?

issue.title: Example in USAGE.md:
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I generated the keys and ceritifcates following the procedure described, but when running the server the connection couldn't be established because I got the error:

error setting certificate
80DBC4E8877F0000:error:0A0000F7:SSL routines:ssl_set_cert_unknown certificate type:ssl/ssl_rsa.c:257:

I have installed Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS and I am using OpenSSL 3.2.0-dev

comment.body:
Hello,

I encountered the same issue. If openssl list -providers is run with the -provider-path option I can see the OpenSSL OQS provider as active.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I generated the keys and ceritifcates following the procedure described, but when running the server the connection couldn't be established because I got the error:

error setting certificate
80DBC4E8877F0000:error:0A0000F7:SSL routines:ssl_set_cert_unknown certificate type:ssl/ssl_rsa.c:257:

comment.body:
> Hello,
> 
> I encountered the same issue. If openssl list -providers is run with the -provider-path option I can see the OpenSSL OQS provider as active.

Ahh -- it works when `-provider-path` is set, but not when unset?! Then you (all) either need to set OPENSSL_MODULES suitably (to the directory where `oqsprovider` is stored) or ensure "modules" is suitably set in "openssl.cnf" (and you load the proper "openssl.cnf"): https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/USAGE.md#activation

issue.title: Compilation ERR: Missing `/include` directory on Arch-based distros
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
A bug appears while compiling `oqs-provider` on Arch-based distros. Happens too on the AUR packages [oqsprovider](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/oqsprovider) and [oqsprovider-git](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/oqsprovider-git).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run Arch Linux or some other distro based on it.
2. A Simple way to get into the error is installing `yay` and running as superuser `yay -Sy --noconfirm oqsprovider`.
3. After building `liboqs` and at the beginning of configuring `oqs-provider` it errors.

**Expected behavior**
A `oqs-provider` shouldn't error and compile just fine. **And it should look for `include` directory inside `/usr` / `/usr/lib` / `/usr/lib64` / `/usr/local/lib` (...) too.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/assets/115881539/259671b3-b8a7-4b5a-a578-07fc88b9d81b)


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: `Artix Linux OpenRC Rolling` / `Arch Linux`
 - OpenSSL version: `3.1.1`
 - oqsprovider version: `latest /0.5.1`

 - OpenSSL: `OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023 (Library: OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023)` 
 - For oqsprovider: 
```
Providers:
  default
    name: OpenSSL Default Provider
    version: 3.1.1
    status: active
```

**Additional context**
 - Command used on the git repository: `cmake -S . -B _build && cmake --build _build && ctest --test-dir _build && cmake --install _build`

comment.body:
basically inside a container you can run `yay -S oqsprovider` or just remove the `CMD ["yay"]` so you can use bash.

> But it fails.

Sorry, I've wrote it quickly without checking.

> Any idea what archlinux / docker do here?

What do you mean?

comment.body:
Thanks for your reply.

I include the lines:

```
oqsprovider = oqsprovider_sect
[oqsprovider_sect]
activate = 1
```

But it's not clear to me if the `-provider-path` line has to be included after `activate = 1`:

```
oqsprovider = oqsprovider_sect
[oqsprovider_sect]
activate = 1 -provider-path /to/oqs/folder
```

issue.title: Compilation ERR: Missing `/include` directory on Arch-based distros
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
A bug appears while compiling `oqs-provider` on Arch-based distros. Happens too on the AUR packages [oqsprovider](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/oqsprovider) and [oqsprovider-git](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/oqsprovider-git).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run Arch Linux or some other distro based on it.
2. A Simple way to get into the error is installing `yay` and running as superuser `yay -Sy --noconfirm oqsprovider`.
3. After building `liboqs` and at the beginning of configuring `oqs-provider` it errors.

**Expected behavior**
A `oqs-provider` shouldn't error and compile just fine. **And it should look for `include` directory inside `/usr` / `/usr/lib` / `/usr/lib64` / `/usr/local/lib` (...) too.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/assets/115881539/259671b3-b8a7-4b5a-a578-07fc88b9d81b)


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: `Artix Linux OpenRC Rolling` / `Arch Linux`
 - OpenSSL version: `3.1.1`
 - oqsprovider version: `latest /0.5.1`

 - OpenSSL: `OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023 (Library: OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023)` 
 - For oqsprovider: 
```
Providers:
  default
    name: OpenSSL Default Provider
    version: 3.1.1
    status: active
```

**Additional context**
 - Command used on the git repository: `cmake -S . -B _build && cmake --build _build && ctest --test-dir _build && cmake --install _build`

comment.body:
> What do you mean?

Please read the above: Your original Dockerfile fails to build. When debugging it, I created a minimal Docketfile (see code above) that does not retain the results of the `chown` command: `chown` is executed; `ls` confirms proper ownership change; later check via `ls` (or logging into the image) shows that "/home/yay" still is owned by root. So all subsequent commands (in your Dockerfile) fail and "yay" does not build.

issue.title: Example in USAGE.md:
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I generated the keys and ceritifcates following the procedure described, but when running the server the connection couldn't be established because I got the error:

error setting certificate
80DBC4E8877F0000:error:0A0000F7:SSL routines:ssl_set_cert_unknown certificate type:ssl/ssl_rsa.c:257:

I have installed Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS and I am using OpenSSL 3.2.0-dev

comment.body:
> But it's not clear to me if the -provider-path line has to be included after activate = 

No; "module=" as you did it.

> I guess that the issue may be caused my something else.

Are you 100% certain that this "openssl.cnf" is loaded? Set OPENSSL_CONF env var explicitly to be sure. Also check that "ls -l /to/oqs/folder/oqs.so" shows the proper binary.

issue.title: Update Kyber and Dilithium to FIPS versions
issue.body:
Once the FIPS drafts are released, we'll need to update Kyber and Dilithium based on the tweaks added by NIST.  

Upstream already has started on this:
- https://github.com/pq-crystals/kyber/tree/standard
- https://github.com/pq-crystals/dilithium/tree/standard

comment.body:
>  up to now I was able to generate the certificates, while the attempt to open a connection fails

Well, if you can generate proper QSC certs then the provider is surely loaded. What happens if you (try to) display the cert (via the `openssl x509` command)? Also, did you build the provider from source code or are you using our docker image "openquantumsafe/oqs-ossl3" (to eliminate any build errors)?

comment.body:
I opened the certificates with `openssl x509 -text dilithium3_srv.crt -noout` and it shows the error 'Unable to load Public Key'.

I build it with the cmake command shown in the README.md

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I generated the keys and ceritifcates following the procedure described, but when running the server the connection couldn't be established because I got the error:

error setting certificate
80DBC4E8877F0000:error:0A0000F7:SSL routines:ssl_set_cert_unknown certificate type:ssl/ssl_rsa.c:257:

I have installed Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS and I am using OpenSSL 3.2.0-dev

comment.body:
>  'Unable to load Public Key'

with 99% certainty means that `oqsprovider` is not active. What is the output of running `openssl list -providers`? What are the key environment variables set to? LD_LIBRARY_PATH, OPENSSL_MODULES, OPENSSL_CONF? Please try the docker image.
